dashboard.title: Dashboard
dashboard.welcomeDescription: Start by scanning a product or browsing categories to see your personalized feed here.
dashboard.errorMessage: Something went wrong loading your dashboard.
dashboard.sparklineAria: Bar chart showing distribution of product scores across health bands
dashboard.subtitle: Here's your food overview for today.

tip.0: Whole grains are rich in fibre, B vitamins and minerals. Choose whole-wheat bread over white bread when possible.
tip.1: The WHO recommends less than 5 g of salt per day ‚Äî roughly one teaspoon. Check sodium on the label.
tip.2: Fruits and vegetables should fill half your plate at every meal for optimal micronutrient intake.
tip.3: Ultra-processed foods (NOVA 4) are linked to higher health risks. Look for NOVA 1‚Äì2 alternatives.
tip.4: Drinking water instead of sugary beverages can cut hundreds of empty calories per day.
tip.5: Reading ingredient lists helps spot hidden sugars ‚Äî look for words ending in '-ose' (glucose, fructose, sucrose).
tip.6: A Nutri-Score of A or B indicates better overall nutritional quality compared to similar products.
tip.7: Saturated fat raises LDL cholesterol. The WHO recommends keeping it below 10% of total energy intake.
tip.8: Dietary fibre supports gut health, lowers cholesterol, and helps regulate blood sugar. Aim for 25‚Äì30 g per day.
tip.9: Food additives (E-numbers) aren't all bad, but NOVA 4 products tend to combine many whose long-term effects are still studied.
tip.10: Portion size matters more than you think ‚Äî even healthy foods add up fast when portions double or triple.
tip.11: Omega-3 fatty acids (ALA, EPA, DHA) support heart and brain health. Look for them in fatty fish, flaxseed, and walnuts.
tip.12: Staying hydrated aids digestion and concentration. Aim for 1.5‚Äì2 litres of water daily, more in warm weather.
tip.13: Front-of-pack labels like Nutri-Score summarise nutrition, but always check the full table for a complete picture.

season.spring: üçì It's strawberry season in Poland ‚Äî explore fresh produce!

landing.description: Search, scan, and compare food products across Poland and Germany. Get instant health scores, allergen warnings, and better alternatives.
landing.featureSearchDesc: Find products by name, brand, or category
landing.featureScanDesc: Scan barcodes for instant product info
landing.featureCompareDesc: See health scores and find better alternatives

legal.contactIntro: Have questions, feedback, or want to report a data issue? Reach out to us.
legal.dataWeCollectText: We collect your email address for authentication, your food preferences and allergen settings, and anonymous usage analytics. We do not sell your data or share it with third parties.
legal.howWeUseText: Your data is used to provide personalized food recommendations, allergen warnings, and health scores. Preferences are stored securely in our database and synced across your devices.
legal.dataStorageText: All data is stored on Supabase (PostgreSQL) hosted in the EU. We use row-level security to ensure you can only access your own data.
legal.yourRightsText: Under GDPR, you have the right to access, correct, or delete your personal data. Contact us at the email below to exercise these rights.
legal.acceptanceText: By using Poland Food DB, you agree to these terms. If you do not agree, please do not use the service.
legal.serviceDescText: Poland Food DB provides food product information, health scores, and nutritional data sourced from Open Food Facts and our own analysis. This is for informational purposes only and does not constitute medical or dietary advice.
legal.dataAccuracyText: While we strive for accuracy, food data may contain errors. Always check product labels for allergen and nutritional information. We are not liable for decisions made based on our data.
legal.userAccountsText: You are responsible for maintaining the security of your account. Do not share your credentials. We reserve the right to suspend accounts that violate these terms.
legal.liabilityText: Poland Food DB is provided "as is" without warranties. We are not liable for any damages arising from the use of this service.
legal.imageWhatWeProcessText: Barcode images (camera-based barcode scanning) and product label images (OCR text extraction ‚Äî Beta feature, coming soon).
legal.imageOnDevice: All image processing happens entirely on your device (in your browser)
legal.imageNeverUploaded: Images are NEVER uploaded to our servers
legal.imageNotStored: Images are processed in temporary memory and immediately discarded after use
legal.imageOnlyText: Only extracted text (barcode numbers or label text) is used for product search
legal.imageCameraText: Camera access requires your explicit permission. You can revoke it at any time in your browser settings. The camera feed is only active while you are using the scanning feature.
legal.imageDataCollectedText: We collect barcode numbers (EAN codes) extracted from barcode scans and, in the future, extracted text strings from OCR processing. We do NOT collect the images themselves.
legal.imageLegalBasisText: Consent (GDPR Article 6(1)(a)) ‚Äî you choose to use the camera feature. Legitimate interest (GDPR Article 6(1)(f)) ‚Äî providing product lookup functionality.
legal.contactText: For questions about these terms, contact us at:

nutriScore.A: Nutri-Score A: Best nutritional quality. Low in fat, sugar, and salt. High in fiber, protein, and fruits/vegetables.
nutriScore.B: Nutri-Score B: Good nutritional quality. Slightly higher in some nutrients than A, but still a healthy choice.
nutriScore.C: Nutri-Score C: Average nutritional quality. Moderate levels of fat, sugar, or salt. Consume in reasonable amounts.
nutriScore.D: Nutri-Score D: Below average nutritional quality. Higher in fat, sugar, or salt. Choose less frequently.
nutriScore.E: Nutri-Score E: Lowest nutritional quality. High in fat, sugar, and/or salt. Consume sparingly.
nutriScore.unknown: Nutri-Score not available. Insufficient data to compute the score for this product.

nova.1: NOVA 1: Unprocessed or minimally processed food. Examples: fresh fruits, vegetables, grains, plain meat, eggs.
nova.2: NOVA 2: Processed culinary ingredient. Used in food preparation. Examples: oils, butter, sugar, salt, flour.
nova.3: NOVA 3: Processed food. Made by combining NOVA 1 & 2. Examples: canned vegetables, cheese, bread, cured meats.
nova.4: NOVA 4: Ultra-processed product. Industrial formulations with additives. Examples: soft drinks, packaged snacks, instant noodles.

score.green: Score 1‚Äì20 (Green): Low health risk. This product has favorable nutritional composition.
score.yellow: Score 21‚Äì40 (Yellow): Moderate health risk. Some nutritional concerns but generally acceptable.
score.orange: Score 41‚Äì60 (Orange): Elevated health risk. Notable levels of unhealthy nutrients or additives.
score.red: Score 61‚Äì80 (Red): High health risk. Significant amounts of fat, sugar, salt, or concerning additives.
score.darkred: Score 81‚Äì100 (Dark Red): Very high health risk. Multiple unhealthy factors at high levels.

confidence.high: High confidence: Most data fields verified. Nutrition, ingredients, allergens, and source information are complete and cross-validated.
confidence.medium: Medium confidence: Key data present but some fields estimated or incomplete. Scores are reliable but may shift with better data.
confidence.low: Low confidence: Significant data gaps. Score may not reflect true product quality. We're working to improve coverage.

concern.0: EFSA Concern Level 0: No known safety concerns. This additive is well-studied and considered safe at typical dietary levels.
concern.1: EFSA Concern Level 1 (Low): Minimal safety considerations. Widely used, generally safe, but some studies suggest monitoring at very high intake.
concern.2: EFSA Concern Level 2 (Moderate): Some safety considerations. EFSA has noted potential effects at high doses. Used in many processed foods.
concern.3: EFSA Concern Level 3 (High): Significant safety considerations. EFSA recommends intake limits. Some countries restrict use in certain food categories.

allergen.present: Contains {name} ‚Äî This product lists {name} as an ingredient.
allergen.traces: May contain traces of {name} ‚Äî Cross-contamination possible during manufacturing.
allergen.free: Free from {name} ‚Äî No {name} detected in this product.

nutrient.low: {nutrient}: {value}{unit} per 100g ‚Äî Low level (FSA green). Within recommended limits.
nutrient.medium: {nutrient}: {value}{unit} per 100g ‚Äî Medium level (FSA amber). Watch your intake.
nutrient.high: {nutrient}: {value}{unit} per 100g ‚Äî High level (FSA red). Limit consumption.

warning.highSugar: High sugar: This product contains {value}g of sugar per 100g, exceeding the 22.5g threshold. WHO recommends limiting added sugar to <25g/day.
warning.highSalt: High salt: This product contains {value}g of salt per 100g, exceeding the 1.5g threshold. WHO recommends <5g salt/day total.
warning.highFat: High fat: This product contains {value}g of fat per 100g, exceeding the 17.5g threshold.
warning.highSatFat: High saturated fat: This product contains {value}g of saturated fat per 100g, exceeding the 5g threshold. Linked to cardiovascular risk.

scoreBreakdown.title: Why this score?
scoreBreakdown.error: Could not load score breakdown. Please try again.

export.nothingToExport: Nothing to export ‚Äî the list is empty.

learn.hubSubtitle: Understand how we evaluate food products
learn.hubDescription: Explore our educational resources to understand the scoring systems, labels, and classifications used in FoodDB.
learn.disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes only. It does not constitute medical or dietary advice. Consult a healthcare professional for personalized nutrition guidance.

nutriScore.title: Understanding Nutri-Score
nutriScore.description: What the A‚ÄìE grades mean and how they're calculated.
nutriScore.summary: Nutri-Score is a front-of-pack label rating food nutritional quality from A (best) to E (worst). It helps you quickly compare products ‚Äî but it's not the whole story.
nutriScore.whatIsText: Nutri-Score is an EU front-of-pack nutrient profiling system developed by Sant√© Publique France and adopted in several European countries. It grades food products from A (best nutritional quality) to E (worst) based on their nutrient content per 100 grams.
nutriScore.howItWorksText: The score combines negative points (energy, sugars, saturated fat, salt) with positive points (fruits/vegetables/legumes, fibre, protein). The final letter grade is determined by subtracting positive points from negative points. Lower results get better grades.
nutriScore.limitationsText: Nutri-Score is useful but not perfect. It does not account for the degree of food processing (a diet soda can score B despite being ultra-processed). It's calculated per 100g, which may mislead for products consumed in small amounts (olive oil scores D). It also ignores food additives and their safety profiles.
nutriScore.unknownText: When we don't have enough nutritional data to calculate a Nutri-Score, or when the product category isn't applicable (e.g., alcohol), the score is shown as UNKNOWN or NOT-APPLICABLE. This is more honest than guessing.
nutriScore.ourApproachText: We use Nutri-Score as one of three independent dimensions. We never rely on it alone to judge a product. Our Unhealthiness Score and Processing Risk fill the gaps that Nutri-Score leaves.

novaGroups.title: NOVA Food Classification
novaGroups.description: Understanding food processing levels from minimally processed to ultra-processed.
novaGroups.summary: NOVA classifies foods into 4 groups based on how much they've been processed. Group 1 is unprocessed or minimally processed; Group 4 is ultra-processed. Higher processing is linked to higher health risks.
novaGroups.whatIsText: NOVA is a food classification system developed by researchers at the University of S√£o Paulo. Unlike Nutri-Score, which focuses on nutrients, NOVA focuses on the degree and purpose of food processing.
novaGroups.group1Text: Foods altered only by drying, pasteurization, freezing, or fermentation without added substances. Examples: fresh fruits, plain rice, eggs, fresh meat, milk.
novaGroups.group2Text: Substances extracted from Group 1 foods used in cooking. Examples: olive oil, butter, sugar, salt, flour.
novaGroups.group3Text: Group 1 foods modified by adding Group 2 ingredients, usually with 2‚Äì3 ingredients. Examples: canned vegetables, artisan cheese, freshly baked bread, traditional pickles.
novaGroups.group4Text: Industrial formulations with 5 or more ingredients, often including substances not commonly used in home cooking (emulsifiers, flavour enhancers, colorants). Examples: chips, instant noodles, soft drinks, packaged snacks.
novaGroups.whyItMattersText: Research shows that high consumption of ultra-processed foods (NOVA 4) is independently associated with increased risk of all-cause mortality, cancer, and metabolic syndrome ‚Äî even when the nutrient profile looks acceptable. A product can have a decent Nutri-Score but still carry high processing risk.
novaGroups.polishContextText: Many popular products in Polish supermarkets like ≈ªabka, Biedronka, and Lidl fall into NOVA 4. This doesn't mean you should never eat them ‚Äî it means being aware of how much of your diet comes from ultra-processed sources.
novaGroups.processingRiskTitle: How we use it: Processing Risk
novaGroups.processingRiskText: In FoodDB, NOVA groups are mapped to three Processing Risk levels: Low (NOVA 1‚Äì2), Moderate (NOVA 3), and High (NOVA 4). This gives you a quick read on processing alongside our Unhealthiness Score and Nutri-Score.

unhealthinessScore.title: Our Health Score
unhealthinessScore.description: How the 9-factor Unhealthiness Score works and what the bands mean.
unhealthinessScore.summary: The Unhealthiness Score (1‚Äì100) is our primary composite metric. It estimates cumulative harm potential by weighting 9 factors: saturated fat, sugars, salt, calories, trans fat, additives, preparation method, controversies, and ingredient concern.
unhealthinessScore.whatIsText: The Unhealthiness Score answers a simple question: if someone ate this product regularly, how much cumulative harm potential does it carry? The scale runs from 1 (low concern) to 100 (very high concern). We deliberately call it 'Unhealthiness' rather than 'healthiness' ‚Äî a score of 30 doesn't mean a product is healthy, it means it's less unhealthy than one scoring 70.
unhealthinessScore.factorSatFat: Saturated fat (weight: 17%) ‚Äî ceiling: 10g per 100g. Based on EFSA daily reference values.
unhealthinessScore.factorSugars: Sugars (weight: 17%) ‚Äî ceiling: 27g per 100g. Based on WHO guideline for free sugars.
unhealthinessScore.factorSalt: Salt (weight: 17%) ‚Äî ceiling: 3g per 100g. Based on WHO 2023 sodium guideline.
unhealthinessScore.factorCalories: Calories (weight: 10%) ‚Äî ceiling: 600 kcal per 100g. Energy density indicator.
unhealthinessScore.factorTransFat: Trans fat (weight: 11%) ‚Äî ceiling: 2g per 100g. EU regulation; WHO says no safe level.
unhealthinessScore.factorAdditives: Additives count (weight: 7%) ‚Äî ceiling: 10 additives. Based on NOVA ultra-processing research.
unhealthinessScore.factorPrepMethod: Preparation method (weight: 8%) ‚Äî deep-fried scores highest due to acrylamide/PAH/HCA formation.
unhealthinessScore.factorControversies: Controversies (weight: 8%) ‚Äî captures product-level issues like palm oil or banned substances.
unhealthinessScore.factorConcern: Ingredient concern (weight: 5%) ‚Äî based on EFSA additive risk tiers (concern levels 0‚Äì3).
unhealthinessScore.band1: 1‚Äì20: Low concern ‚Äî plain oats, raw vegetables
unhealthinessScore.formulaText: Each factor is normalized to 0‚Äì100 (using scientifically-justified ceilings), multiplied by its weight, and summed. The result is clamped to 1‚Äì100. When data is missing, that factor defaults to 0 and the data completeness score is reduced.
unhealthinessScore.whyDifferentText: Nutri-Score ignores processing degree, food additives, preparation methods, and controversies. Our Unhealthiness Score fills those gaps by incorporating all nine factors into a single number backed by WHO, EFSA, and EU regulatory thresholds.

additives.title: Understanding Additives
additives.description: What E-numbers are, EFSA concern tiers, and how to read additive lists.
additives.summary: Food additives (E-numbers) are substances added to food for preservation, color, taste, or texture. Not all additives are dangerous ‚Äî many are perfectly safe. EFSA evaluates their safety, and we use their risk tiers to help you understand the difference.
additives.whatAreText: E-numbers are codes assigned by the European Union to approved food additives. The 'E' stands for 'Europe' (and also 'edible'). Every additive used in EU food must be evaluated by EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) and receive an E-number before it can be used.
additives.notDangerousText: Many E-numbers are completely natural and safe. Citric acid (E330) is found in lemons. Lecithin (E322) comes from soybeans or eggs. Ascorbic acid (E300) is vitamin C. The E-number system simply means the substance has been evaluated for safety.
additives.concernTier0: Tier 0 ‚Äî No concern: Water, sugar, salt, flour. Basic ingredients with no safety issues.
additives.concernTier1: Tier 1 ‚Äî Low concern: Lecithins (E322), citric acid (E330). Well-studied, generally recognized as safe.
additives.concernTier2: Tier 2 ‚Äî Moderate concern: Some artificial sweeteners and colorants. Safe at approved levels but subject to ongoing research.
additives.concernTier3: Tier 3 ‚Äî High concern: Nitrites (E250), BHA (E320), certain azo dyes. EFSA has flagged concerns; some have reduced ADIs.
additives.howWeUseText: In FoodDB, each ingredient is assigned a concern tier based on EFSA evaluations. The product's ingredient concern score (0‚Äì100) contributes 5% to the overall Unhealthiness Score. Products with no concerning additives score 0 on this factor.
additives.polishContextText: Polish food labeling follows EU Regulation 1169/2011. All additives must be listed by their E-number or full name in the ingredients list. When shopping at ≈ªabka or Biedronka, check the ingredient list ‚Äî shorter lists with recognizable ingredients generally indicate less processing.

allergens.title: Allergens in Food
allergens.description: EU mandatory allergens, Polish label reading, and 'contains' vs 'may contain'.
allergens.summary: EU law requires 14 allergens to be clearly declared on food labels. Understanding the difference between 'contains' and 'may contain traces of' helps you make safer choices.
allergens.eu14Text: Under EU Regulation 1169/2011, these 14 allergens must be highlighted in the ingredients list whenever they are present:
allergens.allergen1: Cereals containing gluten (wheat, rye, barley, oats, spelt)
allergens.allergen8: Tree nuts (almonds, hazelnuts, walnuts, cashews, pecans, Brazil nuts, pistachios, macadamias)
allergens.containsVsTracesText: 'Contains' means the allergen is an ingredient in the product. 'May contain traces of' (or 'produced in a facility that also processes...') is a voluntary warning about potential cross-contamination during manufacturing. It is not legally required but is widely used.
allergens.polishLabelsText: On Polish packaging, allergens in the ingredients list are highlighted in bold or UPPERCASE. Look for 'Alergeny:' or 'Zawiera:' (Contains:) sections. The Polish terms for common allergens: mleko (milk), jaja (eggs), pszenica (wheat), soja (soybeans), orzechy (nuts), sezam (sesame), seler (celery), gorczyca (mustard).
allergens.inFoodDBText: We track allergen data from product labels and cross-reference it with ingredient lists. When allergen information is available, it's shown on the product profile page.

readingLabels.title: Reading Polish Food Labels
readingLabels.description: How to interpret nutritional tables, per-100g vs per-serving, and mandatory elements.
readingLabels.summary: Polish food labels follow EU regulations and contain standardized nutritional information. Learning to read them helps you compare products fairly and make informed choices.
readingLabels.nutritionTableText: EU law requires all pre-packaged food to display a nutritional declaration. The table must include: energy (kJ/kcal), fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugars, protein, and salt. All values are given per 100g (or per 100ml for liquids).
readingLabels.per100gText: The per-100g column allows fair comparison between products ‚Äî it's the standard used by Nutri-Score and our Unhealthiness Score. The per-serving column is optional and depends on the manufacturer's defined serving size, which can vary widely. Always check the serving size when using per-serving values.
readingLabels.mandatoryItem2: Ingredients list (sk≈Çad) ‚Äî in descending order by weight
readingLabels.mandatoryItem3: Allergens ‚Äî highlighted in bold or UPPERCASE
readingLabels.mandatoryItem5: Best before / Use by date (najlepiej spo≈ºyƒá przed / nale≈ºy spo≈ºyƒá do)
readingLabels.tip1: Always compare per 100g values, not per serving ‚Äî serving sizes differ between brands.
readingLabels.tip2: Check the ingredients list length ‚Äî shorter usually means less processed.
readingLabels.tip3: Look for the first 3 ingredients ‚Äî they make up most of the product.
readingLabels.tip4: Watch for sugar under different names: syrop glukozowo-fruktozowy, maltodekstryna, dekstroza.
readingLabels.tip5: The EAN barcode (kod kreskowy) is the product's unique identifier used in our database.

confidence.title: Data Confidence
confidence.description: What verified, estimated, and low confidence mean for our product data.
confidence.summary: Not all product data is equally reliable. We use three confidence levels ‚Äî Verified, Estimated, and Low ‚Äî so you always know how much to trust the scores you see.
confidence.whyText: Our Unhealthiness Score is only as good as the data behind it. Some products have complete, label-verified nutritional data. Others have gaps we've filled with estimates. We believe in being transparent about this.
confidence.levelVerified: Verified ‚Äî All data comes from the primary label source. Every nutrition field has been confirmed against the actual product packaging. This is the highest confidence level.
confidence.levelEstimated: Estimated ‚Äî Some values have been estimated from category averages or similar products. The score is reliable but may not match the exact label values.
confidence.levelLow: Low ‚Äî Significant data gaps exist. The score should be treated as approximate. We display it so you have some information, but we clearly mark the uncertainty.
confidence.completenessText: Each product has a data completeness percentage (0‚Äì100%) based on 15 checkpoints: EAN code, 8 nutrition fields (calories, fat, saturated fat, carbs, sugars, protein, salt, fibre, trans fat), Nutri-Score, NOVA classification, ingredients, allergen assessment, and source provenance. Currently, most products in our database are at 87‚Äì100% completeness.
confidence.howWeImproveText: We continuously update product data from multiple sources: manual label entry, Open Food Facts API, and user reports. When better data becomes available, scores are recalculated automatically.
confidence.whatYouCanDoText: If you notice incorrect data for a product, you can help improve our database. Look for the confidence indicator on each product profile ‚Äî it tells you how reliable the current data is.

watchlist.title: Watchlist
watchlist.subtitle: Products you are monitoring for score changes
watchlist.loadError: Could not load your watchlist. Please try again.
watchlist.emptyDescription: Start watching products from their profile page to track score changes and reformulations over time.

recipes.title: Recipes
recipes.loadFailed: Could not load recipes. Please try again.
recipes.emptyDescription: Try adjusting your filters or check back later for new recipes.

overnight-oats.title: Overnight Oats with Yogurt & Berries
overnight-oats.description: Creamy overnight oats topped with fresh berries and a drizzle of honey.

steps.1: Combine oats, yogurt, and milk in a jar. Stir well.
steps.2: Cover and refrigerate overnight (or at least 4 hours).
steps.3: Top with fresh berries and a drizzle of honey before serving.

jajecznica.title: Polish Scrambled Eggs (Jajecznica)
jajecznica.description: Classic Polish-style scrambled eggs with butter and chives.

steps.1: Melt butter in a non-stick pan over low heat.
steps.2: Crack eggs into the pan and stir gently with a spatula.
steps.3: Cook slowly until just set but still creamy. Season and serve with chives.

zupa-pomidorowa.title: Tomato Soup (Zupa Pomidorowa)
zupa-pomidorowa.description: Traditional Polish tomato soup served with noodles or rice.

steps.1: Saut√© diced onion in butter until soft.
steps.2: Add crushed tomatoes and vegetable broth. Simmer 15 minutes.
steps.3: Blend until smooth, season with salt and sugar.
steps.4: Serve with cooked pasta or rice.

chicken-salad-yogurt.title: Chicken Salad with Yogurt Dressing
chicken-salad-yogurt.description: Light chicken salad with a creamy yogurt-herb dressing.

steps.1: Grill or poach chicken breast and slice thinly.
steps.2: Toss mixed greens, cucumber, and tomatoes in a bowl.
steps.3: Mix yogurt with lemon juice, garlic, and herbs for dressing.
steps.4: Top salad with chicken slices and drizzle dressing.

baked-salmon-vegetables.title: Baked Salmon with Roasted Vegetables
baked-salmon-vegetables.description: Oven-baked salmon fillet with seasonal roasted vegetables.

steps.1: Preheat oven to 200¬∞C. Season salmon with olive oil, lemon, and herbs.
steps.2: Toss vegetables with olive oil and spread on a baking sheet.
steps.3: Place salmon on the sheet and bake for 20 minutes.

ingredients.2: 1 cup mixed vegetables (zucchini, bell pepper, onion)

pierogi-simplified.title: Simple Potato & Cheese Pierogi
pierogi-simplified.description: Simplified pierogi with a potato and farmer's cheese filling.

steps.1: Make dough: mix flour, egg, water and a pinch of salt. Knead until smooth.
steps.2: Prepare filling: mash boiled potatoes with farmer's cheese and season.
steps.3: Roll dough, cut circles, fill and pinch edges to seal.
steps.4: Boil pierogi until they float. Serve with caramelized onions.
steps.5: Optionally pan-fry boiled pierogi in butter until golden.

yogurt-nuts-honey.title: Greek Yogurt with Nuts & Honey
yogurt-nuts-honey.description: Quick, protein-rich snack with crunchy nuts and sweet honey.

steps.2: Top with mixed nuts and a drizzle of honey.

hummus-vegetables.title: Hummus with Fresh Vegetables
hummus-vegetables.description: Creamy hummus served with colorful vegetable sticks.

steps.1: Blend chickpeas, tahini, lemon juice, garlic, and olive oil until smooth.
steps.3: Serve hummus with vegetable sticks for dipping.

ingredients.4: Carrot, cucumber, and bell pepper sticks

red-lentil-soup.title: Red Lentil Soup
red-lentil-soup.description: Hearty and warming red lentil soup with cumin and lemon.

steps.1: Saut√© onion, carrot, and garlic in olive oil.
steps.2: Add lentils, cumin, and broth. Bring to a boil.
steps.3: Simmer 20 minutes until lentils are soft.
steps.4: Blend partially, season with lemon juice and salt.

mediterranean-quinoa-salad.title: Mediterranean Quinoa Salad
mediterranean-quinoa-salad.description: Fresh quinoa salad with cherry tomatoes, olives, and feta.

steps.1: Cook quinoa according to package directions and cool.
steps.3: Toss quinoa with vegetables, crumbled feta, olive oil, and lemon juice.

green-smoothie.title: Green Smoothie
green-smoothie.description: Nutrient-packed green smoothie with spinach and banana.

steps.1: Add all ingredients to a blender.
steps.2: Blend on high until smooth. Add more liquid if needed.
steps.3: Pour into a glass and serve immediately.

baked-apples-cinnamon.title: Baked Apples with Cinnamon
baked-apples-cinnamon.description: Warm baked apples with a cinnamon-oat crumble topping.

steps.1: Preheat oven to 180¬∞C. Core apples and place in a baking dish.
steps.2: Mix oats, cinnamon, honey, and a little butter for the filling.
steps.3: Stuff apples with the mixture and bake 25 minutes.
steps.4: Serve warm, optionally with a spoonful of yogurt.

imageSearch.title: Image Search
imageSearch.description: Take a photo of a food label and we'll find matching products. All processing happens on your device ‚Äî images are never uploaded.
imageSearch.processingDetail: Extracting text from your photo on-device
imageSearch.ocrFailed: Could not read text from image
imageSearch.unusableTip: Very low confidence ‚Äî try a clearer photo with good lighting and hold the camera steady.

privacy.title: Your Privacy Matters
privacy.body: Image Search processes photos entirely on your device. No images are ever uploaded to our servers.
privacy.bullet1: All processing runs locally in your browser
privacy.bullet2: Photos are deleted from memory immediately after scanning
privacy.bullet3: No image data is stored or transmitted
privacy.bullet4: Only the extracted text is used to search for products

capture.instructions: Take a photo or upload an image of a food label
capture.tips: Tip: For best results, ensure good lighting and hold the camera steady.
capture.cameraError: Camera not available. Please upload a photo instead.

results.title: Extracted Text
results.lowConfidence: Low confidence ‚Äî review and edit the text below before searching.
results.noText: No text could be extracted. Try a different image.
results.imageDeleted: Image was deleted from memory ‚Äî your privacy is protected.

badge.highTooltip: Data is complete and cross-validated from multiple sources.
badge.moderateTooltip: Key data is present but some fields are estimated or incomplete.
badge.lowTooltip: Significant data gaps ‚Äî treat scores as estimates.

scoringVersion.label: Score v{version}
scoringVersion.tooltip: This product was scored using formula v{version} ({factors}-factor model).

sourceAttribution.title: Data Sources
sourceAttribution.noSourceData: Source attribution data is not yet available for this product.
